comments.text:
Hi Braveheart,
thank you for posting this dragonfly box. I really like it, but I noticed after printing, that the lid is too big for the box. It is a really excellent fit otherwise and just a shame that it is too long. Let me know if you happen to change it to the right size! I considered trying to do it, but there's actually a lot of work needed and I don't think I can do it from an .STL file. I'm not sure if it would be easy for you to do or not but if you do, let me know. Oh and I'm not asking you to do this either, but if you do change it, I might suggest that it would be nice if one end ie 2 adjoining faces, of the lid didn't include a step and were just flat so they would sit flush with the side of the box once it was closed, and essentially they would complete the top edge of the box.
Just to be clear, I am not criticising the box design! I really think it is a beautiful box! I just wanted to let you know about the size and suggest the edge adjustment.

title: Printrbot Clip-On Filament Guide and Cleaner

description.text:
2-in-1 Filament guide and Cleaner that simply clips on to your extruder motor. No screws, glue, or part removal required.  
The Filament Guide serves to restrain or centre the filament feed to the GT2 pulley and roller to avoid slips. As the Z axis retracts sometimes the filament can get pushed forward. This can lead to shredding if the filament is not centred on the pulley and roller.  
The Cleaner portion holds cleaning material of your choice, some use sponges, even lubricate them a little with oil, I use packing peanuts.  
EDIT:   The design minimises contact with the motor and if you have a fan, it allows airflow through to keep your extruder motor cool. I also forgot to mention, snap away the support material on the inside of the cleaner portion (I dislike Repetier's options). No additional print support needed.

author: R0N7N

description.text:
Brackets/Sides for solar panel breakers 12v solar circuit should be protected by a fuse or a circuit breaker. You need at least three breakers. However the breakers are designed to be installed into a special enclosure. In a case of 12v solar system you can have stand alone breaker by using a designed cover brackets.
XMM65 and TOB1Z are identical breakers. The breaker cover has left and right brackets. The top four holes (to have an access for the screwdriver) are covered by screws or plugs. When printing the plugs do adjust the infill percentage settings close to 100%.
Left and right brackets are different. To connect the brackets together please use 3x40 mm bolts.
Safety note: even 12 v can be dangerous. This housing is designed to be used by a responsible and knowledgeable person. It is your responsibility to work safe with 12 volt equipment. I wouldn't accept any of your problems with wrong wiring, etc.

description.text:
I've designed a Jig/holder/frame using magnets that allows to disassemble the HP ElitePad 900 and 1000 series without too much effort. The Jig is too large to print in one piece so it's broken up into several pieces and firmly connected with special connectors that are part of the printed objects. The attached stl file is scaled to 60% of the real object in order to make it visible. Some links about the commercial device info:-
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T4-F7fT3rzY http://gadgets.itwriting.com/2165-hp-elitepad-900-a-tablet-that-is-easy-to-disassemble-thanks-to-magnetic-screen-attachment.html If there is enough interest I'm willing to publish all the source files, instructions and all necessary components. The magnets should only be positioned in a specific direction. Please let me know what you think and whether it's worth publishing.

This is the final result after testing and tweaking my original peristaltic pump(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:664381). This final version is self priming and has enough pressure to gain at least 6' elevation( I ran out of hose). There are a couple choices as far as the pump body is concerned, vented or solid motor housing and a base that either holds an arduino uno or an adafruit perma-proto quarter-sized breadboard pcb (https://www.adafruit.com/products/589) The biggest change in hardware was the addition of one 608 bearing for a total of 4 and two lock-nuts on the rotor to keep things in place. I'm using a 5v 28BYJ-48, the ULN2003 driver board that it came with and powering it through an arduino. (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0089JV2OM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). I designed the pump around 1/16" I.D. x 1/8" O.D. Silicone Tubing (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00G9C9H20/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). You will also need 4 608 bearings, two 6-8mm m3 bolts & nuts to attach motor, two m3 28mm bolts & nuts to attach the rotor case cap ,two 6mm m3 bolts & nuts to attach the motor housing to the base, attachment points for the driver board and microcontroler are all m3 as well, glue to attach the rotorCap and a microcontroller. I'm currently using the pump with an arduino uno to take sail moisture reading, record them and water when necessary.

comments.text: Hi, nice design.  Have you ever considered using the more common 1/8" ID tubing that they use for aquariums?  Just wondering, as I use that type of tube for hydroponics as there are a lot of irrigation accessories made for it as well.
comments.author: seravi

comments.text: The main thing you need to be concerned with when selecting a tube to design a peristaltic pump around is the ability of the tubing to be compressed until an airtight seal is formed then rebound repeatedly.  Much of the tubing used in aquariums does not meet these requirements, so designers tend to select silicon tubing for inside the pump itself.  You can connect to more typical and cheaper tube types once you are outside of the pump.
comments.author: seravi

description.text:
Why pay ~$20 for a fan mounted reservoir adapter when you can make your own?  
This custom made design can be paired to any case or radiator to hold a full reservoir for your liquid cooled computer. With the supplied SKP models, you can even scale it to any size you might prefer (like 140mm).  
The mounting position is intentionally offset for structural rigidity and helps to raise or lower the installation height of your reservoir depending on the orientation.

title: FPV simple camera and transmitter module

description.text:
I made this simple camera module to easily transfer fpv to other RC models. Mounting systems uses stripe of velcro at the bottom.   
Main parts are TAROT 600TVL camera or similar and boscam 300mW transmitter. There is extra part for antenna, if needed to bend 90 degrees.   
Last image shows power cable for this camera and that's all you need to mount this. With suitable connector you can really easily fpv anything without any fuzz.

You 3D print don't you? I bet you go through tons of snap blades for print clean-up.  
Now, the responsible thing is of course to embed the snapped-off blade segments in a spare piece of foam. But admit it, you don't always have those lying around and just chuck your bits into the bin.  
This simple tool lets you snap off your blades without having to pry out that pesky end clip at the back of your blade. Just snap it off in the slot and let the piece drop into oblivion.  
Unlike piggy banks, the container is designed to prevent it's contents from falling back out, because nothing comes back from oblivion.  
Dispose of the entire container once full.  
UPDATE: Large version uploaded for the larger 18mm blades! I don't have any large blades on me though. So do let me know if the large one works!

The parts are designed for easy printing, no tough overhangs and bridges if you print slot-side down. (it's the default orientation, just FYI in case something messes up)  
Takes about an hour to print at 0.3mm layer height. A bit more for the Large version.  
Advisable to print in PLA since these are meant to be disposable parts and will eventually make their way into the bin.

title: Playpi a Raspberry pi 2 case for retropie

description.text:
Update 2015-05-03 B
--
The new overclock base is up.
It is done so the cool air from the fan should circulate on the top and bottom of the raspberry pi 2 and then exit on the side with the cable inputs. Update 2015-05-03
--
Cleaned up and decreased print times on the top pieces.
if you got errors on the first use these instead.
The one with fan extension is for my overclock mod to have a small 40mm 5v fan to circulate the air on the top and bottom of the pie to allowe a modest overclock on the raspberry pi 2 when it is in the case.
Iam working on the base piece.
The default base piece v2 is simply also only cleaned up and fixed to have a smaller print time , so if you printed the orginal no nead to download and print this. Published 2015-05-02
--
I did not want a plain squared case so I remixed a cool one I found here on thingiverse.
Its intended for retro pie builds but its up to you.
Its done in tinkercad the free cad prg.
Video.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hkyOuK_MzQQ

comments.author: MontagueFlange

comments.text:
You nead to get the low amp fans that works by plugging straight on the pi pins them self :)
it have a couple of 3v and 5 v pins active by default and any unused pin acts as - ground.
I could plug it in very easy on sda and 5v in the corner end of the pi.
http://www.instructables.com/files/orig/FN1/YEKZ/HN824U1E/FN1YEKZHN824U1E.jpg

title: For the UP3D Mini. Injector stepper motor cooler for PLA filament use.

description.text:
The filament stepper motor on the UP3D Mini gets VERY hot and when using PLA the heat can cause the stepper motor gear which feed the filament to the nozzle to start slipping and this can lead to a stripped gear on the feeder mechanism.
I made this cooler to fit around the motor on the two sides visable. I fixed a small heatsink onto the side facing the door and used heatsink fixing strip around the edges of this device to glue it firmly to the motor.
The fan is 40mm and available with the heatsink at Maplins locally for a few pounds.
The Fan sucks in cold air from the 'chimney' across the motor and heatsink blowing out towards the door of the printer which can be left open. The 12 volt supply for the motor was taken from the plug which supplies power to the original fan on the other side of the print head with no problems.
The fan mounting is sufficiently distant from the stepper motor to prevent any magnetic conflicts which would cause it to stop.
The cooling effect is excellent.

One simple STL file. Print it on it's side, chimney down to save plastic. Here is a link for the heat sink and fan that I used:-
http://www.maplin.co.uk/p/akasa-ak-vcx-01-universal-cooling-kit-n57gu
I stuck the heatsink directly onto the motor casing just behind the fan.
If you need any further information, I will be most happy to assist you, just let me know.

Thanks for providing the file!

author: Brandon11

title: Compensator to counteract the force of the belt of the X-axis (Prusa i3)

description.text:
Compensator to counteract the force of the belt of the X-axis while avoiding the deformation of the smooth rods of the Z-axis.  
Use metric screws of 3x20 mm and secure the support of the X-axis with glue fast.  
Adjust the screws with the belt of the X-axis loose.

comments.text:
It is difficult for me to explain it.
Do this test, place the Z axis in the middle of the rods, loosen the strap and if you have a caliber take the depth measurement in the holes in the right bracket. Tighten the strap, you will see that the measurement has decreased and the Z-axis rods have arched. This piece prevents the deformation of the rods.
Adjust it with the loose strap and without exerting any pressure on the X-axis rods, tightening the strap will keep the correct distance avoiding deformation of the Z-axis rods.
comments.author: cisko

author: n602

description.text:
I designed it to help my self with my electronic hobby.
I had two versions. First one you will see as a first jpg image - I printed bottom and top of the box using my Replicator 2.
Test shows that printed thing is not sutable to hold liquid...
This why in a second version the major part of the box was glued using plexiglas.
Fill yourself free to contact me on PCB design or source code for Atmega8

• Do not print things with "sborka" in the name - it is just to illustrate the final construction
  • Things with "vannochka_stand" in a name are the things need to be build from plexiglas. I made them using CNC. If you going to do them mannualy please adjust sizes because i use some slots
  • the rest is for printing (mostly head of the box + box for microcontroller)
    • all was designed to be printed without raft and without support

comments.text:
Great design! I'm considering building a similar box.
One general question: I imagine you used ABS as printing material. Is PLA also etch resistant? I'm using sodium persulfate for etching.
I think I could save some time, if somebody has any experience. :)
comments.author: Doubleyou

comments.text: I'm using PLA. It depends on what you mean by resistant. My printing thing is resistant to chemicals but not holding any liquid - liquid is goin away because of many small holes in a body of a thing. The bottom of my second version etching box is from plexiglas. The top was printed because fro top it is less critical to hold liquid. I also use some glue and brush to cover my top thing.

title: The Whitney Museum of American Art

description.text:
The Whitney Museum of American Art, designed by Renzo Piano and built by Turner, marks the start of the High Line in the West Village of Manhattan. The museum has the city's largest column-free art gallery, an education center, theater, a conservation lab and a library and reading rooms. This model served as a working model during the construction process to help explain the building's multifaceted elevations and complex geometry. Click here to learn more about this project:

description.text: The Star Tetrahedron is constructed from 10 Foldable Tetrahedron base units. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:78075. 8 of the tetrahedron are assembled as normal. 2 of the tetrahedron are partially folded and then assembled together into an octahedron. A tetrahedron is attached to each face of the octahedron forming the star tetrahedron. The final object looks like 2 large tetrahedron intersecting.

-Printed 10 Foldable Tetrahedron base units. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:78075
-Assembled 8 tetrahedron and 1 octahedron (8 sides) using hot glue.
-Removed excess hot glue from edges of assembled base units.
-Scored thin cross hatching lines with hobby knife on faces of octahedron and on the bottom of each tetrahedron.
-Used hot glue to attach a tetrahedron to each face of the octahedron. Initially tried used Zap-A-Gap CA+ brand glue with poor results. This glue has worked well on other plastic projects but not on this PLA print. Would like to see this thing made using two colors. Possibility of using this concept to create much larger structures. Imagine a 3D printer group meetup where everyone brings interchangeable base components to create a sculpture. I write about Making and 3D printing in the classroom at designmaketeach.com

remixed_from.author: Telnoi
remixed_from.title: Eye One Xtreme - custom battery tray incl. receiver/rx attachment back-plate

description.text: This is a remix of Telnoi's excellent EOX Battery Frame/Frame Stiffener.  All that I did was add landing gear to Telnoi's great design.

Printed with PETG. 6 layers and 20% infill. It weighs less than the stock battery frame and landing gear that it replaces (12.1g vs 13.6g). The fact that it strengthens the frame is a major bonus. I've made it with different lengths of legs, but (so far) am only uploading what I consider a decent "generic" length.  
Also, I only used the 4 bolts on the booms to hold it in place along with wrapping the velcro around the underside of the main frame and through the slots on this frame (then, of course, around the battery).   
When you print it out, it seems a little dainty, but when it's bolted in place, it's solid as a rock!   
I just uploaded a second iteration with slightly longer and thicker legs. If you're prone to "hard landings", this one will take the abuse a little more. If you're printing with your own printer, you can stop the print wherever you want if you want shorter legs (I'd say any time after 65% or more).  
Looking at the last pic, you can see the difference in the thickness of the legs. Not a ton, but definitely more sturdy (and 1g heavier).

comments.text:
Seems like you reverse mounted the tray, which is fine by me ;)
It does make the Rx backplate a bit more prone to breaking when the quad crashes.
comments.author: Telnoi

comments.text: Reversing it, It was a perfect fit. I always mount the RX on the rear leg. The secondary antenna mounted perfectly on the RX plate putting it up front, and everything fit perfectly. I just went over and looked at it again. If that plate breaks in a crash, in all likelihood there would be such damage to the quad that it would be the least of my worries (plus I can print another in a whole two hours of print time!)... :p

remixed_from.author: enif
remixed_from.title: Double Hinged 12864 Full Graphics LCD Frame

description.text: As I usually print directly from the PC, I do not really depend on having a display controller attached to my Prusa i3. However I do like to have a display, because it is quite convenient to be able to control the printer off-line, to adjust the print rate while printing, or just to check the temperatures while cooling down after the PC has already been switched off. The often used 2004 smart and the full graphics display controllers are rather large, they occupy with their two 10-pin cables a lot of the unused pins (especially on Sanguinulolu, which only has a few of those) and their backlight LEDs draw quite a lot of current from the 5V supply. So when I first saw one of these tiny OLED 128x64 I2C displays, I thought that these were just what I needed to build a a simple DIY display controller: it is much smaller, uses less pins and draws less current and - since it also works on 3.3V! - it can also be used with the Arduino Due. The result is the tinyOLED display controller which is described with all technical details in the RepRap forum. This project here presents printable frames for the 0.96" and 1.3" versions of the 128x64 I2C OLED displays, both available for a few dollars on eBay. Both versions use the same PCB and the frames only differ in the cutout for the active area of the display. In its simplest configuration, the controller only needs an 8-wire connection to the RAMPS or the Sanguinololu (or just 7, if you don't need the audible click from the buzzer). If desired or required, a standard microSD-card module (less than 2$) can be plugged into the read of the PCB, which requires 4 more connection wires. The files provided with this project include the SCAD source as well as STLs of the frames for the 0.96" and 1.30" display versions and the tinyOLED PCB version 1.3. Also contained are the STLs for a snap-in rear cover and a knob for the rotary encoder. For completeness I also included the PCB layout. Note that the PCB also allows for an optional 24Cxxx type EEPROM, which might be useful for Arduino Due users. The tinyOLED frame is compatible with the same double hinge mechanism that I already used in my frames for the Smart 2004 LCD and the Full Graphic 12864 LCD controllers. So for more details about assembling the hinge mechanism, please look there. If you fixed mounting, use M4 screw that a fit the M4 nyloc nuts which must be inserted into the the nut traps which you will use for mounting. In addition to the left and right mounting nuts, there it is also possible to use a central mount on the bottom. Be carful with the central bottom mount not to use too long screw, as this could cause shorts and damage the electronics. Update 2015-05-08: I have now uploaded a new version of the TinyOLED display frame which has the rotary encoder mounted on the side, which results in a more compact frame and a more intuitive use.

The frames were printed from 3mm ABS filament on my DIY Prusa i3 using a 0.4mm nozzle with 0.56mm extrusion width and 0.252 layer height.  I print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape but thoroughly cleaned with acetone and double concentrated lemon juice.

comments.text:
Just printed and there's just no way the 1,3" can fit in there. The case should be 3-5mm "higher" for the PCB to fit in there.
I got mine from http://www.hkmakers.hk/
edit: I printed the 130 complete.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: Hkmakers.hk are selling a different PCB with their own layout, but unfortunately they are now using the same name I used for my project. Their PCB is not compatible with the PCB I designed and published with this project (see the PDF PCB layout file and also the technical description in the RepRap forum linked to in the main description). So it's clear that the hkmakers' board will not work with my STLs. But since you also have access to the OpenScad source, you can always try to adapt the SCAD file for for the hkmakers board...
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: That's a shame.. thought they were the same actually. Thank you for clearing it up. Will make an adaptation at some point (remix from yours),

title: polo 6n (and probably lot more old VW's) rear window sprinkler replacement

description.text:
Sprinkler for rear window in one of my (actually only) retro cars got broken and lost long time in The Past. As shooting random people with window cleaner fluid while you try to wipe back window was probably funny as in youtube video, but not really appreciated by people who are personally concerned , i've decided to print replacement nozzle. It will definitelly fit 3 door version of 1996 VW polo 6n.
It might fit other VW cars about this date (probably up to 2001) like jetta, golf, etc. v2 uses slightly larger nozzle sizes - pick it if your printer can't print v1 reliably. v3 - i think final version. it sprinkles where it should, it can be locked securely, and it got improved shape to allow excess fluid to drop from it's bottom tip instead of spoiling VW logo below. Also it got (most) overhangs resolved.

After printing you need to clear interior supports with sharp knife.
also apply a (stainless) nut in the trap - you'll probably need to heat it up to and push it in as the trap is bit fishy in design. next step is positioning the wiper locking nut.
There are two methods for this - hardware or software :)
for software version (good route if your nut is rust-stubborn to the wiper and you don't want to spoil antique value of your car) you need to open blender file and rotate the 'wiper lock nut' along z axis. this might require change of position of locking parts aswell. for hardware route
you might need some kind of washer (brass , stainless, teflon) or just a bit of well. Force ;). you need to just place nut in proper position (so when you apply sprinkler it's nozzle is in 'top' position) once nut is in proper position you might try to push the new sprinkler on top of it - it should fit snugly, if not - use hobby knife or small file to make it happen.
test it throughly - it should work even without locking As sprinkler gives fair amount of pressure, it's good idea to use some sort of glue (like silicone or acryclic) to seal the voids - just don't sprinkle before it fully cures.
ofcourse there is also locknut mechanism to finally secure it to the nut If anything does not work as you would expect it to (like you get your car fluid sprinkling all over to front window instead of back like it happened with my prototypes ;) - you can tweak the (provided) blender source file.
good luck!

  • These needed a large amount of modification (cutting the base, grinding the pegs
    • http://www.amazon.com/Guitar-Tuning-Machine-Tuners-replacement/dp/B0099DMFK2/

title: Wiimote GloveClip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a derivative of the wii remote and challenges the idea that all of a devices features are built into it at the factory... A swivel clip to attach a Wiimote to a glove and allow it to swing freely in circles. For a game I'm working on. If you are interested in helping me develop this game shoot me an email... Used lots of stuff from thingiverse.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8029
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7544
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1299 TODO:
Make it thinner.
Secure the wiimote better.
Make the tolerances tighter.
Make the fabric connector round and smaller.
Possibly add stuff for a diy rotary endcoder. (Might not need to).
Make the game.

Step one: Attach the WiimoteGloveClipLock and star to palm of glove.
Step two: Cut a small hole in the palm of the glove over the large hole in the center of the GloveClipLock.
Step three: Attach wiimote to WiimoteGloveClip.
Step four: Put on glove.
Step five: Snap the WiimoteGloveClip into the GloveClipLock.
Step six: Spin that Wiimote like a madman!
Step seven: ?????
Step eight: Profit! The Lock ver 1 works but is big. Ver 2 is thinner but doesn't hold the wiimote as well.
Ver 4 of the clip doesn't work with anything but lock ver2.
Ver 3 of the clip works with the first lock but it is very thick. Basically the best combo at the moment is Gloveclipver2 glovecliplock and gloveclipstarver2

comments.text: I used three items making this, one was CC share-alike and the other two items were licensed as CC non-commercial.  Can I use a CC non-commercial license or do I need to make my item share alike? In a more generic sense, what do you do when you are modifying two objects with dissimilar licenses that both allow remixing?
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: That is a great question -- my first inclination was that you just add the two licenses together and make it cc-by-sa-nc....but that turns out to be wrong - and is actually a bit irritating. Here is the official answer
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: Could I ask you to give me a waiver on the share alike part of your license?  Then I can keep CC NC and not step on anyone's toes...  I promise to keep sharing but I  cant license under the SA because of the NC license on stuff that the other people contributed.
comments.author: jpearce

comments.text: I switched to BY SA NC.  I think that will satisfy all of the requirements so long as no one attempts to make a derivative of the individual parts.
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: If I remember right, the NC doesn't apply after you redo it. Could very easily be wrong, though.
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: When in conflict does sharing override non-commercial or visa versa?

title: Coffee grinder funnel timer panel lid

description.text: A lid for a funnel on a doserless coffee grinder. Works perfectly for this funnel:http://item.taobao.com/item.htm?spm=a230r.1.14.37.7drDpD&id=36283576794&_u=b1q35k8d94bf# Which works great for a doserless conversion to a Mazzer Super Jolly.

comments.text: Thank you for posting this, specially the link to the funnel. Ill be doing this on my Fiorenzato grinder. Do you have a link to the arduino part of the project. I can imagine how I would set it up, but having a proven one would be easier.
comments.author: gildardo

comments.text: I am planning on doing a doserless conversion soon. I have a timer that a friend made that sits off to the side and routes the power through it. I like the way this looks, do you have more info on how you built it/how it wires into the grinder?
comments.author: grimeywelsh

comments.text:
Sure. The timer uses an Arduino nano to control the screen and timer function. The arduino takes power from a small 12V power supply that draws its power from the mains supply.
It then uses two solid state relays to replace the contactor (AC relay) that the grinder uses to control the motor - this part will vary depending on the grinder you are using. For your grinder, it sounds like you would be best using a single SSR to switch the mains supply to the grinder.
Let me know if you want any more info - its a fairly simple project if you have any prior experience in electronics and Arduino use.
comments.author: grimeywelsh

title: Parametric nose pad for glasses / spectacles

description.text:
I needed replacements for my spectacle pads and couldn't be bothered to wait for my optician to get them back in stock, so I designed this!  
Developed in openSCAD, just alter the settings within the openSCAD file or in customizer to generate your customised replacement nose pads for your glasses.  
Prints well at 0.2mm layer height - print time for a pair is very quick, roughly 5 minutes (excluding heating time).  
v2 - added pin rotation variable to allow for pins aligned at a different angle to the pad

Measure the dimensions of your existing pads, put the values into customiser (remembering that the length and width of the pad are radii, not diameters), download and print!  
You may need to iterate a few times with different pin settings, depending on how accurate your printer is.

description.text: 3D printable planters.  Make sure to use PLA or you might kill your plants.  These planters have an interlocking feature so you can print multiple cups and lock them together.  It is also easily scalable for bigger or smaller plants.
Use minimum infill settings.  These are great with a 5% infill.  The "floating holes" are supported with a thin solid layer that can easily be cut out.  So, you do not need support material.

A cute tiny desktop garden.
I design it as a present for my beloved wife. Check the instructions tab for more info.

I've printed it in white 1.75 mm ABS under the following parameters: ·3 perimeters
·50% infill honeycomb pattern
·0.2 mm layer height It prints out well. After printing was finished, I filled the watering cans and the pots with water to ensure there wasn't leakages. For the dropper I've used a 3 ml plastic Pasteur Pipette. Cut out the bulb of the pipette with at least 5 mm of the tube remaining. Then glue it to the dropper printed part.
